awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Turbulence, Structures, and Diffusive Shock Acceleration
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will further our understanding of the origin and properties of highly energetic particles accelerated at shock waves in outer space.  Shock waves in the interplanetary and interstellar medium are known to accelerate charged particles to very high (relativistic) energies. Exactly how this is done remains an important open problem. Energized particles irradiate the Earth, satellites and astronauts orbiting the Earth, and spacecraft exploring the heliosphere and other planets. Highly energetic particles represent a hazard to biological systems and technological systems, including communication, positioning, and observational and research satellites. Thus, determining the origin and subsequent properties of very energetic charged particles can have important technological and biological consequences that impact our daily lives and even the national security of the US.  This award will support a collaborative effort between the University of Alabama - Huntsville and the New Mexico Consortium, with support from the Department of Energy, to investigate the effects of complex plasma structures that are typically generated at shock waves on the production of highly energetic particles in interplanetary space.
 
This project will, for the first time, develop quantitative and testable models of particle energization in shock generated turbulence, which is in turn dissipated via reconnection current layers, associated magnetic plasmoids, and particle energization. The coupling of diffusive shock acceleration (DSA) and particle acceleration in the turbulent wake of fast shocks cleaves naturally into two: A) the generation, transmission, and amplification of turbulence and structures at collisionless shock waves, and B) the coupled acceleration of electrons and ions at and in the turbulent wake of collisionless shocks. This project will 1) develop models, validated by simulations that describe the transmission and generation of turbulence through and at collisionless quasi-perpendicular and quasi-parallel shock waves; 2) determine whether collisionless shocks can generate magnetic structures downstream of the shock and will describe the downstream evolution of shock-generated structures through reconnection-related processes; 3) explain the interaction of magnetic structures and current sheets, including the heliospheric current sheet, with incident shock waves; and 4) use numerical models and observations of turbulence, magnetic structures, and current sheets interacting with shocks to develop a theory of particle acceleration in the vicinity of shock waves.

por.por_cntn:
The standard mechanism typically invoked to explain the energization of particles locally in the solar wind is that of diffusive shock acceleration (DSA). However, detailed interplanetary observations are not easily interpreted in terms of the simple original steady-state models of particle acceleration at shock waves. Three fundamental aspects make the interplanetary problem more complicated than the typical astrophysical problem: the time dependence of the acceleration and the solar wind background, the geometry of the shock, and the long mean free path for particle transport away from the shock. Despite the success of the coupling of DSA to CME-driven shocks in explaining many SEP observations, numerous examples of energetic particle events simply cannot be accounted for by DSA, especially those that exhibit characteristics of obviously local acceleration or intensity profiles that possess features that suggest additional acceleration processes. For example, sometimes energetic particle flux enhancements are observed well beyond several correlation lengths downstream of a shock, i.e., too far to allow accelerated particles to return to the shock front for further acceleration.

 

Intellectual Merit: The idea that local structures and dynamical processes associated with low-frequency (MHD) turbulence may affect particle transport and acceleration in the heliosphere is not new, but it has attracted considerable attention recently through a convergence of theory, simulations, and detailed observations. In particular, this grant has supported the state-of-the-art theoretical modeling of particle transport in dynamical turbulence dominated by interacting small-scale flux ropes or magnetic islands. Related simulations by a graduate student supported through this grant and collaborating with scientists at Los Alamos National Lab confirm the ability of dynamical colliding small-scale magnetic islands (SMIs) to contribute to local particle acceleration. Furthermore, in the case of shock waves, time-intensity profiles of the energetic particle flux mediated by small-scale flux ropes downstream of a shock were predicted to be “amplified” over their value at the shock front. This is distinctly different from the predictions for a pure DSA case, which predict a “1” plateau. Such events were both predicted by the theory and confirmed by numerous observational studies supported by this grant. In summary, 1) This gratn led to the development of a comprehensive transport theory that describes the propagation and energization of charged particles, primarily ions, in dynamically evolving low frequency turbulence comprising small-scale magnetic flux ropes aka small-scale magnetic islands. This grant has brought the development of these theories to the state-of-the-art. 2) Solutions to the transport phenomenology have provided the first quantitative comparison of predictions to observations, finding quite remarkable success. A series of papers compared successfully energetic particle distributions downstream of shock waves in the supersonic solar wind and downstream of the heliospheric termination shock, and energetic particle distributions in the vicinity of the heliospheric current sheet, which is expected to generate and trap numerous magnetic islands, to predictions. 3) Numerical simulations have compared in detail their results with those predicted from the theory, identifying in particular the importance and role of the different physical energization mechanisms incorporated in the theory. 4) Finally, new simulations have begun to explore the complicated problem of electron energization in the context of solar physics, identifying a potentially important novel energization mechanism via an electron Kelvin-Helmholtz instability within ion scale magnetic islands.

 

Broader Impacts: A primary broader impact was the training and professional development of a graduate student working towards his PhD, and, as part of that training, fostering an extended collaboration between UAH and LANL. As part of the collaboration, the student spent three consecutive summers doing collaborative research in a national lab environment (LANL), where he was eventually employed as a post doc. The LANL co-PI played an integral role in mentoring the student and became an adjunct associate professor at UAH and was a member of the student’s PhD thesis committee.
